results.name: List consisting of the representation of n in base 3 using -1,0,1 for n=1,2,3,4,...
comment: Every natural number n has a unique representation as n = Sum_{i=1..k} e(i)*(3^i) for some k where e(i) is one of -1,0,1. Example: 25 = 27-3+1 = 1*3^3+0*3^2+(-1)*3^1+1*3^0 so its representation is 1,0,-1,1. So by writing n in this base 3 representation and juxtaposing we get the sequence: (1), (1,-1), (1,0), (1,1), (1,-1,-1), ...
reference: D. E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, Vol 2, pp 173-175.
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..4560 (rows 1 <= n <= 729 = 3^6, flattened)
formula: n = Sum_{0 <= k < A134021(n)} a(A134421(n)-2-k)*3^k, for n>0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 25 2007
example: First 27 rows, with terms aligned with powers of 3:
mathematica: Array[If[First@ # == 0, Rest@ #, #] &[Prepend[IntegerDigits[#, 3], 0] //. {a___, b_, 2, c___} :> {a, b + 1, -1, c}] &, 32] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jun 27 2020 *)
